cards.contribution: Discovered the alpha helix structure of proteins and defined the nature of the chemical bond
The woman behind the equation
The Architect of Bioenergy
Developed Gleevec (imatinib), first targeted cancer therapy for CML
John Hardy identified the first genetic mutation causing Alzheimer?s disease and proposed the amyloid cascade hypothesis, transforming how scientists understand and target neurodegeneration.

Kiyoshi Nagai pioneered the structural biology of the spliceosome, transforming our understanding of gene expression by proving through atomic-resolution imaging that this massive molecular machine is a dynamic, RNA-driven ribozyme.
Engaging with diverse perspectives is essential for fostering innovation and driving meaningful progress.

G. Marius Clore's primary contribution was the development of multidimensional NMR spectroscopy techniques, which allowed scientists for the first time to determine the high-resolution 3D structures of large proteins and nucleic acids directly in a liquid solution.
She discovered t-loop structure and the sheltering complex, proving the telomeres protect the chromosomes ends by tucking away a sailor's splice.

Dieter S?ll fundamentally expanded our understanding of the "universal" genetic code by discovering the indirect pathways organisms use to synthesize proteins and validating the existence of the 21st amino acid, Selenocysteine.

Martin Karplus revolutionized the field of biochemistry by developing multiscale models and molecular dynamics simulations that transformed our understanding of proteins from static "brass models" into dynamic entities governed by "jigglings and wigglings".
Master of DNA Untangling

Hugo Theorell revolutionized enzymology by being the first to split the "yellow enzyme" into its two essential parts?a protein and a vitamin-derived cofactor?thereby revealing the chemical mechanism of how enzymes facilitate cellular respiration.

Richard Willst?tter pioneered the application of rigorous organic chemistry to biological problems, fundamentally reshaping biochemistry by determining the chemical structures of plant pigments, most significantly revealing the magnesium-porphyrin core of chlorophyll.
Ruth Sager shattered the "nuclear monopoly" by discovering non-Mendelian inheritance in Chlamydomonas, proving for the first time that genetic material exists outside the cell nucleus.

Meyerhof revealed that muscle energy metabolism is a cyclical and thermodynamically coupled process, and it displayed how lactic acid that is produced without oxygen will later be recycled back into glycogen by means of energy from oxygen consumption.
She discovered the radioactive elements polonium and radium, fundamentally changing our understanding of atomic science and medical treatment.
Solved the first atomic structure of transfer RNA (tRNA), revealing how the genetic code is physically translated into proteins.
Jewel Plummer Cobb advanced cancer biology through groundbreaking melanoma research while transforming higher education by expanding access and equity for underrepresented scientists.
"He discovered HIF-1, the molecular switch that enables cells to sense low oxygen levels and activate the genes necessary for survival."
He discovered the intracellular sensor NOD2, establishing the first genetic link between the innate immune system's detection of bacteria and Crohn?s disease.

Helmut Beinert revealed the hidden role of iron?sulfur clusters in metabolism by identifying the ?impossible? g = 1.94 EPR signal, transforming how scientists understand electron transfer and catalysis in enzymes.

Efraim Racker pioneered the field of bioenergetics by isolating the F1 ATPase subunit and using it to reconstitute a functional energy-producing system, proving that life?s fuel is generated by a molecular motor.

Noboru Mizushima?s primary contribution was the biochemical characterization of the Atg12 and LC3 conjugation systems, which provided the first molecular explanation for how autophagosomes?the cell?s recycling machinery?are physically constructed and marked in mammals.

Heinrich Matthaei?s primary contribution was the conception and execution of Experiment 27Q, which successfully decoded the first "word" of the genetic language by proving that the RNA sequence poly-U directs the synthesis of the amino acid phenylalanine.

Tu Youyou isolated the heat-sensitive compound artemisinin from sweet wormwood using a low-temperature extraction method inspired by ancient texts, creating a breakthrough treatment that has saved millions of lives from malaria.

Kristala L. Jones Prather transformed modern biochemistry by engineering microbes into efficient chemical factories, enabling sustainable production of valuable compounds through synthetic metabolic pathways.

Dagmar Ringe transformed structural biochemistry by proving that enzymes are dynamic, ?breathing? machines, discovering the protein glass transition and enabling scientists to freeze and visualize catalytic reactions in motion.
Developed yeast artificial chromosome?based physical maps of human chromosomes that laid the foundation for the Human Genome Project and enabled rapid discovery of disease-causing genes.

Patrick Hsu pioneered next-generation CRISPR technologies?extending gene editing from DNA to RNA and programmable genome rearrangement?fundamentally expanding how scientists can read, write, and reprogram genetic information.

Suzanna Lewis transformed modern genomics by co-founding the Gene Ontology Consortium and developing the informatics standards necessary to translate massive amounts of raw DNA sequence data into a universally understood language of biological function.
Krebs was a pioneer scientist in the study of cellular respiration, a biochemical process in living cells that extracts ATP from food and oxygen.

Dennis Selkoe?s most significant contribution is his pioneering formulation of the amyloid cascade hypothesis, which posits that the accumulation of amyloid-beta protein in the brain is the primary trigger for Alzheimer's disease pathology.
Emil L. Smith helped found molecular evolution by showing that protein amino-acid sequences preserve a record of evolutionary relationships across species.
Feodor Lynen was a German biochemist who made foundational contributions to our understanding of metabolism and lipid synthesis, earning the 1964 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.
Thomas Burr Osborne transformed biochemistry by proving that proteins are chemically distinct molecules whose specific amino acid compositions determine their nutritional and biological value.

Tom Maniatis revolutionized molecular biology by pioneering cDNA cloning techniques and co-authoring the definitive laboratory manual, "Molecular Cloning," which transformed gene manipulation from an "occult" art into a standardized global practice.

Maria Jasin demonstrated that creating a targeted DNA double-strand break activates homologous recombination in mammalian cells, a discovery that made precise gene editing?and ultimately CRISPR?possible.
Identified LC3 as the first reliable mammalian autophagosome marker, enabling real-time visualization of autophagy.

Mitchell Guttman revolutionized the field of genomics by discovering that long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) function as essential structural "scaffolds" that organize the 3D architecture of the nucleus to precisely regulate gene expression.

Vulimiri Ramalingaswami transformed global public health by proving that simple nutritional interventions, especially iodized salt and iron supplementation, could prevent widespread disease and protect hundreds of millions from malnutrition and disability.

Franz-Ulrich Hartl revolutionized biochemistry by proving that protein folding in the cell is not always spontaneous, but often requires "molecular chaperones" to provide a protective environment and prevent toxic aggregation.

Theodor Schwann revolutionized biology by proving that the cell is the fundamental building block of all animal life, effectively unifying the plant and animal kingdoms under a single biological theory.

Har Gobind Khorana was a Nobel Prize-winning biochemist who deciphered the genetic code by mapping how nucleotide triplets translate into amino acids and achieved the world?s first chemical synthesis of a functional gene, laying the groundwork for modern genetic engineering.

Thomas S?dhof decoded the molecular "logic" of the brain by identifying the protein machinery, specifically synaptotagmin, that allows neurons to release neurotransmitters with the near-instantaneous precision required for human thought and movement.

David Allis proved that histone modifications are actively written by enzymes, most famously showing that Gcn5 is a histone acetyltransferase, transforming chromatin from a passive DNA package into a dynamic, biochemically regulated system controlling gene expression.
Carol Greider co-discovered telomerase, the enzyme that maintains and extends chromosome ends (telomeres), a breakthrough that transformed our understanding of aging, cancer, and cell division.
Reuben Shaw is a cancer metabolism pioneer who revealed how the cell?s energy ?fuel gauge? (AMPK), controlled by the tumor suppressor LKB1, links metabolism, diabetes drugs, and cancer growth.

James Black revolutionized medicine by applying the "lock and key" principle to pharmacology, designing "rational" drugs like beta-blockers and H2-antagonists that precisely block specific cell receptors to treat heart disease and stomach ulcers.

Thomas Charles Bruice revolutionized the life sciences by founding the field of bioorganic chemistry, providing the foundational molecular framework for understanding how the physical laws of organic chemistry govern the complex catalytic power of biological enzymes.
The Era Selected is when Lydia Lynch discovered the Policemen of the Abdomen, which was one of her more significant findings in her career.
Carl June pioneered CAR T-cell therapy by engineering patients? own T cells with synthetic receptors to hunt and destroy cancer cells, leading to the first FDA-approved ?living drug? for cancer.
Significant work on X-Ray crystallography in photosynthetic intermediates

Britton Chance revolutionized biochemistry by developing high-speed electronic instrumentation, such as the stopped-flow apparatus, which provided the first experimental verification of the transient enzyme-substrate complex and mapped the fundamental respiratory stages of the mitochondria.
He synthesized DNA in vitro to characterize DNA polymerase and was an important figure in the discovery of DNA ligase.
Keith D. Watenpaugh revolutionized biochemistry by pioneering the refinement techniques that allowed scientists to visualize precise structures of proteins for the very first time.
Miescher was the first scientist to isolate DNA, which he called nuclein, from the nuclei of white blood cells.
William Rose mapped the fundamental requirements of human life by discovering threonine, the final essential amino acid, and establishing the precise dietary standards for protein nutrition.
Rosalind Franklin used X-ray crystallography to produce images of DNA.
Isolated the first enzyme, diastase, and identified cellulose as the universal component in plant walls.

He pioneered the X-ray diffraction analysis of DNA fibers and provided the critical experimental evidence, including the deduction of the external phosphate backbone,that verified the double helix structure.

Rosalyn Yalow revolutionized modern medicine by developing the radioimmunoassay (RIA), a Nobel Prize-winning technique that uses radioactive isotopes to measure incredibly tiny concentrations of hormones, vitamins, and viruses in the human blood.
3 dimensional model behind hemoglobin
Jane Dyson overturned the long-held "lock and key" dogma of structural biology by proving that many proteins lack a fixed 3D shape and instead rely on intrinsic, flexible disorder to function.
Bridging Biology and Code
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1SuWKhymvXs2BQLQkePPdRLggpukwC2YSWEU9ySTsKP0/edit?usp=sharing. This is the link to the deep research.
Gertrude Erika Perlmann clarified the structure and mechanism of the digestive enzyme pepsin, laying foundational groundwork for modern protein chemistry and enzymology.

Paul Karrer elucidated the molecular structures of vitamins A, B2, and E, transforming these nutrients from mysterious "vital factors" into synthesizable organic compounds that could be mass-produced to combat malnutrition.
Louis Pasteur's groundbreaking discovery that microorganisms cause fermentation and disease led to the development of the germ theory, revolutionizing microbiology and public health practices.
J. Michael Bishop fundamentally changed our thinking about cancer by showing that it arises from mutations in normal genes rather than external foreign viruses.
Philip Handler mapped the metabolic Handler-Preiss Cycle, proving that dietary niacin is the essential architectural precursor the body uses to synthesize the critical electron carrier NAD+

Johann Deisenhofer's primary contribution was determining the first high-resolution 3D structure of an integral membrane protein, specifically the photosynthetic reaction center, which revealed the atomic-level "blueprint" of how sunlight is converted into chemical energy.

Aviv Regev pioneered foundational experimental and computational methods in single-cell genomics, enabling a revolutionary understanding of the molecular circuits that govern human cells and tissues in both health and disease.

Miroslav Radman revolutionized our understanding of genetic stability by co-discovering the methyl-directed mismatch repair mechanism and conceptualizing the SOS response, demonstrating that biological survival and evolutionary innovation often rely on a regulated balance of genetic fidelity and "infidelity."
She identified the essential chaperone network required to successfully fold and assemble functional plant Rubisco.

James Bonner provided the first experimental proof that histone proteins are not merely structural packaging, but active gene repressors that must be removed or modified to allow DNA to be transcribed.

Melissa J. Moore helped transform RNA biology into a therapeutic reality by revealing how mRNA is processed and controlled in cells and then translating that knowledge into the mRNA technologies that underpin modern vaccines.
Helped identify the SIR genes and experimentally demonstrate epigenetic inheritance of transcriptional silencing in yeast.
Revealed translational control of hemoglobin synthesis through heme-regulated mechanisms and clarified hemoglobin breakdown into bilirubin, foundational to molecular hematology.

She discovered and characterized $\phi29$ DNA polymerase, a highly efficient enzyme that revolutionized genetics by allowing scientists to amplify tiny samples of DNA into quantities large enough for full genomic analysis.

Junying Yuan is a pioneering cell biologist whose landmark research established that cell death is a genetically programmed and biochemically regulated process rather than an accidental event, most notably through her discovery of the evolutionarily conserved role of caspases in apoptosis and her identification of necroptosis as a form of programmed necrosis.

Jonathan Seth Weissman is primarily recognized for inventing ribosome profiling to monitor protein synthesis at nucleotide resolution and for developing CRISPR-based systems like CRISPRi and CRISPRa to precisely regulate gene expression without permanently altering DNA.

Howard Chang revolutionized our understanding of the genome by discovering that "junk DNA" actually contains long noncoding RNAs that act as a biological operating system to control gene activity and cellular identity.

Victor Ambros revealed that tiny non-coding RNAs, later named microRNAs, act as powerful regulators that fine-tune gene expression after transcription, uncovering a hidden layer of genetic control essential to development and disease.

Christiaan Eijkman provided the first experimental evidence for the existence of vitamins by demonstrating that the fatal disease beriberi was caused by a diet of polished rice and cured by the nutrient-rich bran.
He was the first to isolate the chemical elements beryllium and yttrium in pure metallic form.
Illuminated life?s energy of flow
Solved the first atomic-resolution structure of a G protein-coupled receptor (rhodopsin), revealing the molecular architecture of visual signal transduction.
Edwin G. Krebs discovered that reversible protein phosphorylation acts as a molecular switch, establishing how enzymes are turned on and off to regulate cellular processes.

Louis Ignarro's definitive proof that nitric oxide acts as a gaseous signaling molecule to relax smooth muscle revolutionized our understanding of cardiovascular physiology and paved the way for the life saving treatments for heart disease and hypertension.
Chaim Weizmann revolutionized industrial fermentation by developing the Weizmann process, which turned starch-rich materials into acetone and alcohols, crucial for wartime munitions production.
Developed single molecule manipulation techniques to measure the mechanical forces of DNA and of DNA molecular motors.
Stephen Bell identified and characterized the Origin Recognition Complex (ORC), the first known eukaryotic protein complex that marks where DNA replication begins.
Raymond C. Stevens pioneering high-throughput techniques to map the complex atomic structures of G protein-coupled receptors.

By sacrificing his own eyesight to the glare of early instrumentation, Gregorio Weber pioneered the use of fluorescence to prove that proteins are not rigid statues, but dynamic, 'breathing' machines?a discovery that transformed our understanding of molecular life.

James Collins pioneered the field of synthetic biology by engineering the first synthetic gene 'toggle switch,' demonstrating that living cells can be programmed with predictable, circuit-like controls to create next-generation diagnostics and therapeutics.
The most versatile strategy for repair pf damage to DNA is nucleotide excision repair

Ray Jui Wu pioneered the first method for DNA sequencing by inventing location-specific primer extension using DNA polymerase, laying the biochemical foundation for Sanger sequencing and modern genomics while also catalyzing global scientific exchange through the CUSBEA program.
